problem_text: a) Let Ω be a countably infinite set. For k ⩾ 2, we define a k-section of Ω to be a partition of Ω into a union of k infinite subsets. Then does there exist a transitive permutation group on Ω that is transitive on k-sections but intransitive on ordered k-sections? P. M. Neumann
answer: Yes, there does. Let U be a non-principal ultrafilter in P(Ω) and let G = {g ∈ Sym(Ω) | Fix(g) ∈ U}. It is not hard to prove that G is transitive on k-sections but not on ordered k-sections for any k in the range 2 ⩾ k ⩾ ℵ0. (P. M. Neumann, Letter of October, 5, 1989.)
